intro: Eriocaulon lanceolatum var. pilosum, commonly known as the hairy spike-rush, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to wetland and marshy environments in tropical and subtropical regions. It belongs to the family Cyperaceae, which includes sedges, and is characterized by its grass-like appearance with slender, cylindrical stems. The plant has narrow, linear leaves that are often covered in fine, soft hairs, giving it its varietal name "pilosum." Its inflorescence consists of a dense spike of small, three-lobed flowers, which are typically pale green to brown in color. This species is adapted to waterlogged soils and plays a role in stabilizing wetland ecosystems.
